recordTypes.name: repository
recordTypes.description: Repositories allow the submission, storage of and access to data (datasets, code and other digital objects) and include (multi)disciplinary, generalist, data type, project and institutional repositories.

recordTypes.name: knowledgebase
recordTypes.description: Knowledgebases synthesise data from a number of sources including published literature, databases and tools, and often have a manual curation component. They are often considered secondary databases as they store data derived from primary sources.

recordTypes.name: knowledgebase_and_repository
recordTypes.description: A type of database that has the features of both knowledgebases and repositories.

recordTypes.name: journal_publisher
recordTypes.description: Journal publisher policies originate from a specific publisher and describe the requirements for data associated with a manuscript submission across all that publisher's journals.

recordTypes.name: journal
recordTypes.description: Journal policies originate from a specific journal and describe the requirements for data associated with a manuscript submission to that journal.

recordTypes.name: project
recordTypes.description: Project policies describe the resources that should be used by researchers to conform to the data requirements of that project.

recordTypes.name: institution
recordTypes.description: Institution policies describe the standards and databases that should be used by researchers funded by the organisation.

recordTypes.name: funder
recordTypes.description: Funder policies describe the standards and databases that should be used by researchers funded by the organisation.

recordTypes.name: society
recordTypes.description: Society policies describe the resources that should be used by researchers to conform to the data requirements of that society.

recordTypes.name: collection
recordTypes.description: Collections are groupings of standard and database records.

recordTypes.name: model_and_format
recordTypes.description: Models/formats or syntax define the representation of information from a conceptual model or schema, and the transmission format, such as XML, CSV or RDF, which facilitate information exchange.

recordTypes.name: metric
recordTypes.description: Metrics are criteria to assesses some aspect of a digital resource, for example - but not limited to - its discoverability. For example, the FAIR Metrics are a set of machine-actionable criteria that allow the assessment of the level of FAIRness of a resource.

recordTypes.name: terminology_artefact
recordTypes.description: Terminology artefacts are semantic objects that encompass controlled vocabularies, taxonomies, thesauri and ontologies. They add an interpretive/translational layer (beyond any that might be provided by the syntax), and enable complex hierarchical grouping and querying of the data.

recordTypes.name: reporting_guideline
recordTypes.description: Reporting guidelines or checklists outline the minimum information that should be reported alongside an experiment or dataset in order to place it into context. These vary from general guidance to itemised prescriptions of the information that should be provided, both in terms of data and associated metadata.

recordTypes.name: identifier_schema
recordTypes.description: Identifier schemata are formal systems for resources and other digital objects that allow their unique and unambiguous identification.

fairsharingRecords.name: Nature - Reporting standards and availability of data, materials, code and protocols
American Heart Association / American Stroke Association journals - Research Guidelines
